intro: Acacia fragilis, commonly known as the brittle wattle, is a small, shrub-like plant native to Western Australia. It is characterized by its slender, often branched stems and small, feathery leaves that are typically alternate and bipinnate. The plant produces yellow flowers in clusters, which bloom from late autumn to early spring. Acacia fragilis is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, showing drought tolerance and a preference for well-drained soils. Its ecological role includes providing food and habitat for various native animals and insects.

It is commonly found in the southern regions of the state, particularly in the wheatbelt and Swan Coastal Plain areas. This plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is often associated with open woodlands and shrublands. It is well adapted to the dry and temperate climate of the region. Acacia fragilis plays an important ecological role in supporting local wildlife and maintaining soil stability.
